prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: [Configuration and correlator setup]: The FIR(42.5um-122.5um) luminosity get from Herschel/SPIRE detection is about 6.74*10^12 Lsolar. We estimate the total IR luminosity as 1.3 times FIR luminosity. We estimate the CO luminosity adopting a IR-CO(1-0) relationship, which is derived with the CO-detected quasars at local and high redshift(Riechers et al 2010). We then estimate the CO(7-6) based on the CO ladder of J1148. Here we request to map the CO(7-6) line emission in C34-6 configuration at about 0.3" resolution. We will tune the four spectral windows in 2.0GHz bandwidth, 128-dual polarization, TDM model, with one window centered at the CO(7-6) line frequency and the other three windows in upper and lower sidebands observing the continuum. Theredshift uncertainties measured with the quasar Lya line emission are about 0.03(or 3000km/s in velocity), which can be easily covered by the 2GHz bandwidth. [Time and sensitivity requirements]: Assuming that we can resolve the line and dust continuum emission in ~4 synthesized beams, the surface brightnesses are estimated to be about 2.4mJy/beam for the CO(7-6) line and 0.4 mJy/beam for the continuum. Thus we ask for an rms of 0.49 mJy/beam per 100km/s channel. This will allow us to detect the line with SNR~5 in each beam in two to three consecutive 100km/s. Based on the sensitivity calculator the total observing time for this science goal is 38.13min ,including the overhead.

[Configuration and correlator setup]: The FIR luminosity get from Hershcel/SPIRE detection is about 6.21*10^12 Lsolar. We estimate the total IR luminosity as 1.3 times FIR luminosity. We estimate the CO luminosity adopting a IR-CO(1-0) relationship, which is derived with the CO-detected quasars at local and high redshift(Riechers et al 2010). We then estimate the CO(7-6) based on the CO lader of J1148. Here we request to map the CO(7-6) line emission in C34-6 configuration at about 0.3" resolution. We will tune the four spectral window centered at the CO(7-6) line frequency and the other three windows in upper and lower sidebands observing the continuum.The redshift uncertainties measured with the quasar Lya line emission are about 0.03(or 3000km/s in velocity), which can be easily covered by the 2GHz bandwidth. [Time and sensitivity requirements]: Assuming that we can resolve the line and dust continuum eimssion in ~4 synthesized beams, the surface brightnesses are estimated to be about 1.88mJy/beam for the CO(7-6) line and 0.33mJy/beam for the continuum. Thus we ask for an rms of 0.38mJy/beam per 100km/s channel. This will allow us to detect the line with SNR~5 in each beam in two to three consecutive 100km/s. Based on the sensitivity calculator the total observing time for this science goal is 41.88min, including the overhead.

We estimate the CO lu minosity adopting a IR-CO(1-0) relationship, which is derived with the CO-detected quasars at local and high redshift(Riechers et al 2010). We then estimate the CO(5-4) based on the CO l adder of BRI1335. Here we request to map the CO(5-4) line emission in C34-4 configuration at about 0.4" resolution. We will tune the four spectral windows in 2.0GHz bandwidth, 128-dual polarization, TDM model, with one window centered at the CO(5-4) line frequency and the other three windows in upper and lower sidebands observing the continuum.The redshift uncertainties measured with the quasar Lya line emission are about 0.03(or 3000km/s in velocity), which can be easily covered by the 2GHz bandwidth. [Time and sensitivity requirements]: Assuming that we can resolve the line and dust continuum emission in ~4 synthesized beams, the surface brightnesses are estimated to be about 3.06mJy/beam for the CO(5-4) line and 0.25 mJy/beam for the continuum. Thus we ask for an rms of 0.5 mJy/beam per 100km/s channel. This will allow us to detect the line with SNR~3 in each beam in two to three consecutive 100km/s. Based on the sensitivity calculator the total observing time for this science goal is 36.42 min ,including the overhead.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The merger-driven model of black hole(BH)/galaxy co-evolution predicts a special evolutionary stage when quasars transform from the dust-obscured phase to a type-1 quasar, characterized by high star formation rate, high BH accretion rate and signatures of late-stage merger activity. Quasars with weak or undetectable UV emission lines (WLQs) are primary candidates of such transition objects: they often exhibit excess FIR dust continuum emission powered by starbursts, while their weak broad lines and high BH accretion argues for an early phase of quasar formation. We will carry out spatially resolved CO and dust continuum observations of host galaxies of six Herschel-detected WLQs at 2<z<3.6 using ALMA. These observations will measure the molecular mass and star formation rate in WLQ hosts, and spatially resolve both CO and dust continuum emission in the galaxies. We will search for signatures of merger activity, and compare the size, star formation efficiency and dynamical mass of WLQ hosts with those of both SMGs and normal quasars to test the hypothesis that WLQs are young quasars, and to place WLQs in the merger-driven evolutionary sequence of galaxy/quasar formation.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Astronomy , Arizona, University of
